attributes.title: Allegheny Technologies: I Am Neutral Now
summary: ATI's Q4 total revenues were down by 35.4%, which looks only marginally better than in Q3, which was overshadowed by an over 41% decline.

attributes.content:
Allegheny Technologies Incorporated (NYSE:ATI) has recently presented its Q4 results, which were marred by a catastrophic loss of $1.12 billion. Just for context, ATI's current market capitalization is slightly north of $2.3 billion. Meanwhile, its Debt/Equity surged to over 244% from 82% in just one quarter. Is something horrible happening with the company? Are these reasons enough to revise my bullish rating to very bearish immediately? I am neutral now, but there are a lot of moving parts here, thus the issue deserves a thorough analysis that is presented below in the article.

Source: Unsplash

A quick recap of the thesis

On November 18, I upgraded ATI to 'Buy' from 'Hold' as I reckoned its recovery prospects had not been priced in fully and that the market-wide phenomenon called "sector rotation" undergirded by the news of the vaccines could bolster its share price in the short term. There were little signs of improvement in its key end-markets that could promise quick sales recovery, namely in commercial aerospace, but 2021 looked much brighter, as the vaccines instilled confidence that restrictions would be eased and the air travel would eventually recover.

Thankfully, I was right, as since then, the stock price has risen by ~37.9%, largely outpacing the S&P 500 (SPY) that has advanced by only ~9%. The total return here does not make sense, as ATI does not pay a dividend.

So, is it time to take profit? Let us delve deeper into the Q4 results first.

The top line: aerospace still suffering

Upon cursory inspection, the Q4 results look utterly lackluster. Though the global economy was slowly recuperating, for ATI, the quarter appeared to be one of the toughest periods of the challenging year, only slightly less severe than Q3. The High Performance Materials & Components segment bore the brunt, as its sales tumbled much deeper if compared to Advanced Alloys & Solutions, by over 55%. The division also coped with a much steeper compression of the EBITDA margin, to just 3.4% from 18.7%.

The Q4 total revenues were down by 35.4%, which looks only marginally better than in Q3, which was overshadowed by an over 41% decline. Its revenues did rise sequentially, which is certainly an inspiring development, but they were still not even near the 4Q19 level of $1.02 billion. The same applies to the results for the year.

The main culprit of this was the asymmetric recovery in its end-markets. In the fourth quarter, most of Allegheny's end-markets continued experiencing the ripple effects of the coronavirus crisis, but while some were enjoying high demand, like the non-cyclical defense industry and electronics, some were navigating rough waters as customers were still unwilling to boost inventory, as they remained skeptical about the short-term demand.

Aerospace (Jet Engine and Airframe), the essential end-market responsible for 34% of the 2020 sales (page 10), suffered from even deeper revenue contraction than in Q3. While total segmental sales were down by 64%, the quarter appeared especially dreadful for Jet Engine, as its revenues plummeted by 72% to $82 million. On slide 6, ATI clarified that it happened partly due to "destocking from specialty materials’ customers," though also highlighted "demand stabilizing." Meanwhile, Airframe encountered akin problems as customers were struggling to reduce excessive inventory; so, sales plunged 49%.

Is the end-market critical to Allegheny's revenues about to shine again? Unfortunately, there is almost no hope that the recovery will begin earlier than in the second half of 2021.

The vaccines are improving the overall outlook for the global economy, but for airlines, 2021 will likely remain full of challenges. For example, one of Allegheny's essential customers Rolls-Royce Holdings (OTCPK:RYCEF), a British aero-engine maker, has recently warned investors that its cash outflow in 2021 would be more substantial than previously guided. The firm thinks it will burn more than £2 billion (~$2.7 billion), as more contagious variants of the coronavirus will restrain global air travel. The company is expecting engine flying hours in 2021 to be ~55% of the pre-coronavirus level vs. 70% anticipated in October. As customers pay Rolls-Royce for the number of hours its jet engines fly, it will take its toll on the top line and cash flows. This, in turn, implies that revenues of ATI's Jet Engine will remain subpar (or there might emerge a receivables problem if Rolls-Royce will encounter severe liquidity issues).

It is also worth highlighting that GE Aviation (GE), another major customer of Allegheny, has recently reported that its 2020 engine sales plunged 48%, while service revenue fell 36%. But though the 2020 results were horrible, the company remains somewhat optimistic, predicting the aerospace sector to enter the recovery phase in the second half of 2021 (slide 9).

Allegheny's forecast chimes well with the expectations of its customers. As it clarified on slide 9, the demand from the end-market would stabilize in the first half of the year and then enter the "modest growth" phase in H2.

Another issue that weighed on the Q4 and 2020 results of the company was sapping demand from the energy sector (including oil & gas and chemical processing). The capex reduction trend triggered by the oil crisis in spring was still in play despite the quick Brent price recovery. The silver lining is that the remarkable growth in defense (+18% QoQ) and electronics (+27% QoQ) again somewhat mitigated the effects of softness in the aerospace, medical, and energy end-markets on the top line.

The positives: focus on cash flows

But what happened with profits? Certainly, lackluster sales and the compression of the gross margin were among the culprits of the catastrophic loss, but the principal issue is that in Q4, Allegheny booked restructuring expenses of over $1 billion mostly related to the operations in Brackenridge, PA. The rationale behind the move, which was announced in December, was to improve the company's profitability by exiting the low-margin standard stainless steel business and focus on high-value materials (like nickel- and titanium-based alloys) to bolster profitability and Return on Capital.

But as a scrupulous investor will notice, almost all restructuring expenses during the period were non-cash, and thus they were added back to net income to arrive at the net operating cash flow. These costs also did no harm to both adjusted EBITDA and non-GAAP net income. So, Allegheny reported the 2020 net CFFO of almost $167 million, which excessively covered net capital expenditures of $130.6 million (see page 9 of the Form 8-K). Of course, a $36.3 million cash surplus is meager, but it is still a result worth appreciating given the magnitude of the crisis ATI had to cope with.

On a side note, investors should not overlook that ATI's definition of FCF differs from one typically used in equity research: it deducts cash used in investing activities from net CFFO and adds back cash contributions to the U.S. qualified defined pension plans (see the reconciliation on slide 14). In this case, its 2020 FCF reached $168.4 million, which was above guidance.

Final thoughts

ATI's rich price gains in late-2020 is a perfect example of how a value stock can trounce the market when growth names look too generously valued and no longer attractive, thus money goes to cyclical players.

But due to this rally, and also because of EBITDA compression, ATI's EV/EBITDA is now at a three-year high of over 17x.

I am now neutral on ATI, but my downgrade has nothing to do with its horrible accounting loss. The key reason is that the stock has already delivered spectacular returns, and future gains look less certain, especially considering that it will not return to revenue growth until 2022, according to analysts. However, I acknowledge the stock price might react to better-than-expected economic data and the news on the improvement in commercial aerospace.

attributes.bio:
Vasily Zyryanov is an individual investor and writer.

He uses various techniques to find both relatively underpriced equities with strong upside potential and relatively overappreciated companies that have inflated valuation for a reason.

In his research, he pays much attention to the energy sector (oil & gas supermajors, mid-cap, and small-cap exploration & production companies, the oilfield services firms), while he also covers a plethora of other industries from mining and chemicals to luxury bellwethers.

He firmly believes that apart from simple profit and sales analysis, a meticulous investor must assess Free Cash Flow and Return on Capital to gain deeper insights and avoid sophomoric conclusions.

While he favors underappreciated and misunderstood equities, he also acknowledges that some growth stocks do deserve their premium valuation, and its an investor's primary goal to delve deeper and uncover if the market's current opinion is correct or not.
